A31A221738DD4163B01EDD79865968CE.description: Assess environmental and economic impacts of past and current land use practices in Saskatchewan (e.g., agriculture, urban development, recreation, and road construction), and describe intended and unintended consequences of those practices on self, society, and the environment, includingsoil degradation.

F89BF126F8254867A82A1B645D082AA8.description: Identify predominant soil types (e.g., black, dark brown, brown, andgrey) and corresponding land uses in Saskatchewan.

DECC057B852540A7888BAEA1899C2A61.description: Classify soil samples according to their characteristics (e.g., sand, loam, and clay composition) and research ways to enrich soils for specific uses (e.g., vegetable garden, road building, dam construction, waste management, and sports field).

92ED9C5D275644C19BEA98CF6995D226.description: Collect, with permission, and examine samples of local soils to determine their physical properties (e.g., colour, odour, texture, presence of organic matter, pore size, and air and water holding capacity).

77A310FC6DB84BB9BF8CF0F1D9A45BD5.description: Relate mechanical (e.g., wind and water), chemical (e.g., acid rain and rusting), and biological (e.g., lichens, mosses, and tree roots)weathering processes to the formation of soils.

70B1BC5B63CF4F7BB2301D7C305C532E.description: Document the natural surface geological features of the local environment and provide explanations for the origin of those features.

73F882A780B04983AA2AE2AB03A76514.description: Differentiate between weathering and erosion, and explain the roleof water in each process.

C86606002EA34B3E9D47477774FFAD27.description: Describe examples of mechanical and chemical weathering of rocks

E3AC8D3B3F644B6DBC19CA3E37A97583.description: Develop and use a classification key for rocks based on physical characteristics and method of formation.

A7D7CE83D9DD45B3BB277C987EA4F8B3.description: Construct a visual representation of the rock cycle (e.g., formation, weathering, sedimentation, and reformation) and relate this representation to the surface geology of Saskatchewan and Canada.

472E6EAEA47A42C495C4D6EDFD3CAC31.description: Explain how geologists use the fossil record to provide evidenceof geological history.

2F66D360F996436AA179D6989219D301.description: Model the processes of formation of the three major types ofrocks: sedimentary, igneous, and metamorphic.

05F9C8D5B30B4FB98D30EBBD73941C3F.description: Investigate the characteristics and formation of the surface geology of Saskatchewan, including soil, and identify correlations between surface geology and past, present, and possible future land uses.

EE64BBBD075F4E329666EC7493C40CDF.description: Research Saskatchewan careers directly and indirectly related toresource exploration.

E0734CF7D7474826B48372EB5CDD3804.description: Identify uses for rocks and minerals, such as healing, recuperativepowers, and ceremonies, which include ideas not explained by science.

2F947ABB5E3F4A28B2C0CE1CAA4ECCA8.description: Suggest solutions to economic and environmental issues related to the extraction of geological resources in Saskatchewan (e.g., managing mine tailings and pollutants; reclaiming open pit mining sites; ecological impact of pipelines; resource depletion; maintaining water quality; and increasing urbanization).

44CD10A1AD2041A89CD972A299348A4B.description: Provide examples of Canadian contributions to the scientific understanding and technological developments related to surface and sub-surface geology and mining, and identify societal and economic factors that drive such exploration and research.

07531DB1CD8F4A96953B5FA58F6780AF.description: Evaluate different approaches taken to answer questions, solve problems, and make decisions when searching for geologicalresources within Earth (e.g., trial-and-error prospecting versus core sampling).

216EAF336F8D4516B4A1940D75FC5588.description: Provide examples of technologies used to further scientific research related to extracting geological resources (e.g., satellite imaging, magnetometer, and core sample drilling).

DCEEC07D3E35417E8F370D62327CB4B2.description: Relate processes used to extract primary mineral resources in Saskatchewan (e.g., open-pit mining, underground mining, and solution mining) to the location, type, and depth of the resource.

51DA2CE281CF402FB9B7936B211FCC60.description: Identify locations of Saskatchewan’s primary mineral resources (e.g., potash, gold, diamond, salt, uranium, copper, and graphite) andtheir primary uses.

84F11F40AEF14C219CFAD28FAE5E6D76.description: Classify rocks and minerals based on physical properties such as colour, hardness, cleavage, lustre, and streak.

74AB86CEFD334BB893D1AB10E17EAC83.description: Distinguish between rocks and minerals using physical samples, pictures, and/or video recordings and identify the minerals most often found in rocks in Saskatchewan and around the world (e.g., quartz, calcite, feldspar, mica, hornblende).

C07EF22839BA46199E688DBA68483789.description: Identify questions to investigate arising from practical problems and issues related to the study of Earth’s geological resources (e.g., “What types of rocks are best for cement-making or road construction?” and “What are some environmental concerns related to open-pitmining?”).

4687EE6FF9A64278B94E6E751F277511.description: Identify locations and processes used to extract Earth’s geological resources and examine the impacts of those locations and processes on society and the environment.

558464827D934449BECE6B76911CAFE0.description: Provide examples of how science and technology affect self and community through understanding, predicting, and minimizing the effects of catastrophic geological events (e.g., earthquake resistant construction, earthquake and tsunami preparedness, and minimizing climatic effects of volcanic eruptions).

0D751BD54B02460CAB6DE29BA16404F5.description: Explain the operation of tools scientists use to measure and describe the effects of catastrophic geological events, including earthquakes and volcanoes (e.g., seismograph, Mercalli intensity scale, andRichter magnitude scale).

7C359EF1FB6B45E39506B336D21DCD61.description: Organize data on the geographical and chronological distribution of earthquakes, tsunamis, and volcanic eruptions to determine patterns and trends in data and relationships among variables.

72C786A70D5348778EE804467C52A6D5.description: Work cooperatively with group members to researchcatastrophic geological events and integrate individual findings into a chronological model or time scale of major events in Earth’s geological history.

75B4ECD9A318483D9B0DEE27E4E71760.description: Describe societal and environmental impacts of some catastrophic geological events, including earthquakes, tsunamis, and volcanic eruptions, which have occurred on or near Earth’s surface and predict the impacts of future events.

1E8CC5847D7842EB9D58B8A5A19B7B88.description: Create models or simulations of the processes of mountainformation and the folding and faulting of Earth’s surface, including movements at diverging, converging, and transform plate boundaries.

A8F30D62F44445588CB0C232C0E1CDA9.description: Construct a visual representation of the composition of Earth, including the crust, upper and lower mantle, core, and innercore.

3A537A21E81747F0B86C1A444A99188C.description: Trace the development of plate tectonics theory as an explanation for movement of Earth’s lithosphere in light of new geological evidence, including knowledge of tectonic plates and movement at plate boundaries.

23ADF17EA62F4232AD6A1195667E35C3.description: Analyze societal and environmental impacts of historical and current catastrophic geological events, and scientific understanding of movements and forces within Earth’s crust.

23C569D275994270810BFB7B98553719.description: Earth and Space Science: Earth’s Crust and Resources (EC)

B1D80546237F439FA67BB9004C6EC917.description: Demonstrate safe and responsible work practices, includingkeeping the work area uncluttered with only appropriate materials present when investigating heat transfer via conduction, convection, and radiation.

85323ABB036C4BF9AB29B9904702F5BE.description: Select appropriate methods and tools for collecting and displaying data and information related to radiant heat.

82909D459B88417198DCCA982C708FFC.description: Design and carry out an experiment to determine differences in the ability of various surfaces to absorb and reflect radiant heat.

AE55837C57A84B809FF6C057A364E34D.description: Evaluate applications of technologies designed to enhance or restrict the transfer of heat energy via conduction, convection, or radiation (e.g., metal frying pans, radiant heaters, home insulation, ovens, convection ovens, thermoses, winter parkas, and heat exchangers) using student-developed criteria.

B54DE8E05F8047C8BE7C52A6EFEDB90C.description: Assess the impacts on self, society, and the environment, of conduction, convection, and radiation in the natural and constructed world (e.g., heating over cities, temperature layers in lakes, thunderstorms, radiant heaters, refrigerators, and convectioncurrents in air or water).

1E4B02E231E14A799504B144A1DD2054.description: Model convection currents in fluids (liquid or gas) and discussthe effectiveness of the model.

DF0527DAF87144969500E71D4C151546.description: Construct a visual or dramatic representation of heat transfer via conduction in a solid.

025AE6822E764029A2C1635D10653278.description: Demonstrate and explain how heat is transferred by the processesof conduction, convection, and radiation in solids, liquids, and gases

5A8A241447BC40469FE52813D4F85161.description: Investigate principles and applications of heat transfer via the processes of conduction, convection, and radiation.

52CD2E91E5B64BB8B4852503A52959F9.description: Explain how evidence gathered while investigating states of matter and changes in states of matter supports or refutes the particle theory of matter.

6CE4B2BBD5694F5BA26A0D1E742510C6.description: Distinguish between heat and temperature using the concept of kinetic energy and the particle model of matter.

9F3E640555F7479D911B26F2C6CBFC41.description: Trace the historical development of different scales (e.g., Kelvin, Celsius, Fahrenheit, and Rankine) and instruments used tomeasure temperature (e.g., liquid-in-glass thermometers, bi-metallic strips, digital thermometers, liquid crystal thermometers, thermocouples, and computer sensors) and discuss the need for standardized measurements of temperature.

D99D915F6478436888EDFB15CF5B21C5.description: Choose appropriate instruments (e.g. alcohol thermometer, temperature probe, and thermocouple) and use them safely, effectively, and accurately for collecting temperature datawhen investigating states of matter and changes ofstate.

0DB5D78AB6644CBF909848CB295ACBB2.description: Create a visual or dramatic representation to explain changes ofstate of matter (e.g., melting, freezing, evaporation, condensation, and sublimation) according to the particle model of matter.

B6A83017E8BF4F24AE2A2135EA60368A.description: Construct and label a heating curve for water, using student-collected data, indicating states of matter and changes ofstate.

13E3CE57CB1B49AEA35B7DA38789F542.description: Conduct experiments to determine the effects of changesin temperature on solids, liquids, and gases.

49FFF19C63CB469A8324E890912C7784.description: Provide examples from daily life that illustrate the effects ofheating and cooling on solids, liquids, and gases.

A40E142D70D648878665ADE3B6409EA0.description: Explain how understanding differences between states of matter and the effect of heat on changes in state provide evidence for the particle theory

ED7A27508ED14C8FA2247615B24B633A.description: Create a photo journal of science- and technology-based careers in the community related to heating and cooling, such as heating systems and equipment contractors, and boiler engineers.

6B413FC17B9547E2891C8F2A58CFFA6E.description: Provide examples of problems related to heating and coolingthat arise at home, in an industrial setting, or in the environment, that cannot be solved using scientific and technological knowledge.

A5A0392B5D5146498182A77DB1776D3F.description: Assess the design of a personally constructed heating or cooling prototype using collaboratively developed criteria.

9AAE5FA3A90A44E58A05E3270CF1D60C.description: Use a technological problem-solving process to design, construct, and evaluate a prototype of a device that will provide a solution to a practical problem related to heating or cooling (e.g., cooking food, keeping food warm or cool for an extended period, keeping a shelter warm or cool, keeping a person warm or cool).

70D104BFBCF64DDB84B6B9785307C367.description: Evaluate the efficiency of different types of home insulation(e.g., sod, straw bales, fibreglass, cellulose, mineral wool, polystyrene, and polyurethane foam) with respect to criteria such as R-value, cost, and resistance to water and air infiltration.

2A6B79BF9DE849B997BD33612CAC5C6E.description: Compare, in qualitative terms, the heat capacities of some common materials, including water, and explain how heat capacity influences choices of materials used in the development of technologies related to clothing, food, and shelter.

D9A2C8D803504180B11EDE1830445ECA.description: Analyze the impact of the design and function of a heating- or cooling-related technology on self and society.

038AF307A0DA469C90368CFF6B1917C3.description: Communicate questions, ideas, intentions, plans, and results of inquiries related to heat transmission using lists, notes in point form, sentences, data tables, graphs, drawings, oral language,and other means.

E1235F739CF34946A535040CD40993DB.description: Illustrate the historical development and the underlying scientific principles of technologies designed to address practicalproblems regarding human heating and cooling needs for food, shelter, and clothing (e.g., oven mitts, survival suits, air conditioning, central heating, thermos, refrigerators, stoves, heaters, home insulation, fleece jackets, and toques).

5333C7C4994D458A933845A1AD4D6F21.description: Assess the impact of past and current heating and cooling technologies related to food, clothing, and shelter on self, society, and the environment.

3142AE18E1654040934D68F23C68B515.description: Research how various science disciplines and engineering fields study and apply scientific knowledge related to solutions.

55155C6313F34AD7B8DAE1047CCAB47D.description: Analyze the effects of technological inventions orprocesses related to solutions (e.g., water softeners, water treatment plants, solution mining, agricultural sprays, insecticides, bleaches, and drain cleaners) on self, community, and the environment.

AC404AB046CE4DAFA8755F4CC0103D07.description: Predict the solubility of a solute by interpolating or extrapolating from student-generated solubility curves.

8C24735E062C4E00A559A9626DF19C5C.description: Design and implement an experiment to investigate the effect of temperature on the solubility of a solution.

C68E55D025554CD3BD442857D6EF25C2.description: Gather and interpret information from various resources(e.g., nutrition labels on foods, newspaper or magazine articles) related to solutions and concentrations ofsolutions

B6B5D2ABBFC54EA3954ED51DB7B45690.description: Investigate the factors that determine how quickly a solute dissolves in a solvent.

76216B99B62D47D0BA9D28DE5BFFA438.description: Value accuracy, precision, and honesty when collectingand reporting data related to concentrations ofsolutions.

021CA58F7CD846AA8C19301AEE79B5EF.description: Create and describe the concentration of student-prepared dilute, concentrated, saturated, and supersaturated solutions using those qualitative terms and quantitative measurements (e.g., parts per million [ppm], g/L, and g/100 mL).

0430D42C714A486D934DC97068E90EB6.description: Describe the characteristics of solutions using the terms solute, solvent, soluble, and insoluble, based on the particle model of matter

C3ABDD7126794E54B158AC8EFE79C1EE.description: Provide examples of solid, liquid, and gaseous solutions and identify which substance is the solute and which isthe solvent in each solution.

4A89C0F7CAA14BBEB65011BBC1CF4EFB.description: Investigate the properties and applications of solutions, including solubility and concentration.

72222B62E1B7474E8193BD950CB66766.description: Identify new questions and problems that arise from what was learned about solutions and mixtures (e.g., “Are there mixtures that cannot be separated?”, “What techniques are used to remove pollutants from air and water?”), including questions that science cannot answer.

5BD8A3F5921147758514608D45657681.description: Use a technological problem-solving process to design, construct, and evaluate a prototype of a process or devicefor separating a mechanical mixture or solution (e.g., purifying drinking water, separating household waste).

19753D6861A24C7BBD4DF7459E181327.description: Discuss intended and unintended consequences of a particular industrial or agricultural technology or process used for separating materials.

CD84B090F60445A5B19BF71CF36F4A2A.description: Describe the scientific principles underlying a past or present industrial technology designed to separate mixtures (e.g., petroleum refining, sewage treatment plant, recycling station, combine, and cream separator).

6F7A3C665D884B32A263255B6F0FEA26.description: Demonstrate knowledge of WHMIS standards by using proper techniques for handling and disposing of labmaterials and following warning label symbols, including common household product symbols, when separating mixtures.

56ADA13EA2604281A9A72811721A9350.description: Use tools and apparatus (e.g., safety glasses, glassware, and Bunsen burners) safely when conducting investigationsinto methods of separating mixtures.

FF20D8A525104A549D7BFF64DFAD7EE1.description: Report the strengths and limitations of a chosen experimental design to determine the effectiveness and/or efficiency of one or more methods of separating mechanical mixtures and solutions.

1FB2C698136A4D9DAEC1F0DCFD2CF58C.description: Design and conduct an experiment to determine the effectiveness and/or efficiency of one or more methods of separating mechanical mixtures and solutions.

ED15664396314F3F9249A9375DDAFA47.description: Describe common household examples of technologiesthat are used to separate components of mechanical mixtures or solutions (e.g., kitchen strainer, oil and air filters).

27EE79E0A50A4C9A9AD4F614F95AB138.description: Trace the historical development of a technology or process used to separate mixtures (e.g., settling, sifting, filtering, fusion, distillation, and chromatography).

EE4D9A97EF1E4B2A9A64EF4DB4D86109.description: Describe methods used to separate the components of mechanical mixtures and solutions, including mechanical sorting, filtration, evaporation, distillation, magnetism, and chromatography.

C0CE7B2B8E9647A8AB043C55DDCA52A7.description: Investigate methodsof separating the components of mechanical mixtures and solutions, and analyze the impact of industrial and agricultural applications of those methods.

43C26D28489E43EDB7AAE9D2A47A3506.description: Generate questions related to differences between mixtures and solutions and rephrase in a testable form (e.g., rephrase a question such as“How sweet isiced tea?”to“What isthe most iced tea that can be dissolved in 500 mL of water at 23°C?”).

2389240AA45741C782BB67371553F799.description: Analyze the usefulness of personally constructed representations of particles and the strengths and limitations of models in science generally.

748D508102284EFBBBEF72427742129D.description: Create models and/or physical representations that depictthe nature of particles in pure substances, mechanical mixtures, and solutions according to the particle model of matter.

93914C3DA8D3492CB27EE4C3CF676E67.description: State the four main ideas of the particle model of matter.

2781605168F447259E30E0D16FB4355A.description: Create mechanical mixtures and solutions using common materials and compare the physical properties of the original materials and the resultant mixture or solution.

24E778CD1B004EB29B35A4AA48066FCE.description: Listen to and consider the ideas of classmates when classifying materials as pure substances or mixtures.

455C5514D8A94558BEFC666F8FE7D942.description: Classify common substances (e.g., Kool-Aid, vinegar, bubble bath, soft drinks, juice, chocolate chip cookies, saladdressings, hand lotion, shampoos, tea, bread, soil, and concrete) as pure substances, mechanical mixtures, or solutions.

598349DEFAE143F3955872BAD7896299.description: Construct a graphic organizer for the classification of matter that includes mixtures, pure substances, elements, compounds, mechanical mixtures, and solutions.

2275A42DBCCA445F9D61C0754AA7FEC4.description: Describe the characteristics of pure substances, mechanical mixtures, and solutions

00B3EDE28D6145F1A70B9EA221E99610.description: Examine a variety of objects and materials, and record qualitative (e.g., colour, texture, and state of matter) and quantitative (e.g., density, melting point, and freezingpoint) physical properties of those objects in a chart or data table.

B5A879555B1A431CB7918C69483CD9A0.description: Distinguish between pure substances and mixtures (mechanical mixtures and solutions) using the particle model of matter

63B84FB3ADAD40DC9343A1642ED7C7F1.description: Provide specific examples to illustrate that scientific and technological activities related to ecosystems take place in a variety of individual or group settings, locally and globally, and by men and women from a variety of cultural backgrounds(e.g., individual and community gardening, impact studies done by environmental engineers, and research done by teams of international scientists).

D5872204FC8E4FD49E5B8269194DAAF2.description: Be sensitive and responsible in maintaining a balance between human needs and a sustainable environment by considering both immediate and long-term effects of their course of action or stated position.

624013F1875148E59D62B542B1F0D241.description: Propose a course of action or defend a given position on a local ecological issue or problem related to natural orhuman influences on a particular ecosystem, taking into account scientific, societal, technological, and environmentalfactors.

0C98E7D7C77C48848B57C4074F7A8528.description: Select and synthesize information from various sources to develop a response to specific questions related to naturalor human influences on a particular ecosystem.

F0612B284DE84208A0FCF3C8267AD1F8.description: Identify and refine questions and problems related to the effects of natural or human influences on a particular ecosystem

EF1C813144664345BC1E6455C1FBE717.description: Predict what a specific ecosystem (e.g., clear-cut forest, abandoned sports field, abandoned farm yard, abandoned rail line, ditch, driveway, or sidewalk) will look like in the future(e.g., 5, 10, and 25 years) based on characteristics of the area and long-term changes observed in similar ecosystems.

D80D20544F924396A324E74188CEA83C.description: Propose ecological questions to investigate arising from practical problems and issues (e.g., “What is the impact of clearing land for farming?”, “How could a community prolong the life of its landfill site?”, “How could a community reduce the amount of garbage it produces?”, “What is the impact of a sports field being constructed in a particular location?”).

97B077E71973419891343B7D74742E2F.description: Identify evidence of ecological succession in ecosystems,using the concepts of pioneer species, climax community, primary succession, and secondary succession, and by identifying changes in plant and animal life in the ecosystem.

A49812FC6AD944D491804F173A6CD157.description: Analyze how ecosystems change in response to natural and human influences, and propose actions to reduce the impact of human behaviour on a specific ecosystem.

0885A7E88816408CA3190A0BBAC8B5AF.description: Provide examples of scientific knowledge that haveresulted in the development of technologies designed to assist in managing aspects of ecosystems (e.g., understanding the effect of nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium on plant growth led to the production of specific formulations of fertilizers, knowledge of how micro-organisms help break down matter led to the development of composting bins).

5A963E77E3AA4F88A2D8DA92B48A05F8.description: Identify and evaluate potential impacts on energy flow and the cycling of matter by the removal of one or more living organisms from a specific ecosystem.

B1BA13FA0F5A4653973C91154CBDDA88.description: Describe how energy passes through ecosystems during the processes of photosynthesis and cellular respiration.

4CB1DF8491D148DBB4F7D80AD9AE36DF.description: Consider observations and ideas from a variety of sources during investigations and before drawing conclusionsrelated to biogeochemical cycles

31EFB1E15AC24BA7B2FF7DF43A025482.description: Design and conduct an experiment to investigate the conditions essential for the growth of plants (e.g., determine whether nutrients in soil are sufficient to support plant growth, determine the influence of sunlight or other formsof light on plant growth).

369E1A3DE33D488B88587B4B93017D84.description: Describe examples of how scientists collect evidence, search for patterns and relationships in data, andpropose explanations to further the development of scientific knowledge about energy and matter flow in ecosystems.

27CF5EF394DF42EAA516CA30EABDD5AF.description: Explain the role of decomposers in recycling matter in an ecosystem.

2EC8144FF0474C019CB7DED6104B342D.description: Analyze the strengths and limitations of models in science generally, and then apply these criteria to evaluate the efficacy of a student model of a biogeochemical cycle.

F75ED141156C43EA8BD1C664C1E80262.description: Model the carbon, nitrogen, and water cycles to illustrate how matter cycles through ecosystems.

A25BBC6AC8614B07BBCE8738FE5CFCA7.description: Illustrate how energy is supplied to and flows through afood web using the concept of ecological pyramids (e.g., pyramid of energy, pyramid of numbers, and pyramid of biomass).

EA5306D25FD64F739CB9365CC3ECBDA3.description: Evaluatebiogeochemical cycles (water, carbon, and nitrogen) as representations of energy flow and the cycling of matter throughecosystems.

D537DDA02D86460E8DE32828F316D641.description: Provide examples of organizations in Canada that support scientific research related to ecosystems (e.g.,environmental conservation groups, federal and provincial government departments, agricultural and marine institutes, universities, and colleges).

F6A3B20767A74575BD19B7ECAC0C4967.description: Construct a classification key, using appropriate scientific terminology, which will enable classmates todifferentiate between producers, consumers, and decomposers.

AA34272745F445888A561534C9337E70.description: Interpret interdependence within natural systems by constructing food chains and food webs to illustrate the interactions among producers, consumers, anddecomposers in a particular ecosystem.

3A953DC4E69F436882B84EFCD0B0FDE5.description: Classify organisms in a variety of ecosystems as producers, consumers, or decomposers and further classify consumers as herbivores, carnivores, or omnivores.

C38F9B27AFB2436BA6D49EC94419534C.description: Identify strengths and weaknesses of different methods of collecting and displaying ecological data (e.g., compare field observations of an ecosystem with observations from a video or television program, compare a food chain with a food web).

FC9BDC66817B454F8BDE13AFA90D0A8D.description: Compile and display ecological data to illustrate the various interactions that occur among biotic and abiotic components of ecosystems.

D523A46DDEE94B8E891F1BCB13460A61.description: Choose and use appropriate instruments (e.g., magnifying glass, thermometer, light meter, hand-held microscope, and digital camera) safely, effectively, and accurately to observe and illustrate biotic and abiotic components of ecosystems.

1F64374A2CEF4E6B8AE2E37107AF1F41.description: Examine the biotic and abiotic components of distant ecosystems using photographs, videos, or onlineresources

19C39923966A4110A0144F9E762F85AD.description: Show respect for all forms of life when examiningecosystems.

33709A49A1D54D9EAA8B93435ACC4710.description: Conduct a field study to observe, record (using sketches, notes, tables, photographs, and/or video recordings), and identify biotic and abiotic components of a local ecosystem.

E8CFE450363245DEA21ECE7B877D322A.description: Provide examples of ecosystems of varying sizes and locations, including their biotic and abiotic components.

7D85325EC921463B9FCFB118DCC23EA9.description: Illustrate the ecological organization of life within the biosphere, using specific examples of species, populations, communities, ecosystems, and biomes.

09559FA4F1BF480A9B25F07DB10F5A7D.description: Observe, illustrate, and analyze living organisms within local ecosystems as part of interconnected food webs, populations, and communities.

E7723A31A3BB418DB78503663BA585F5.description: Describe the ways that traditional Indigenous knowledge about respect and responsibility for the land, self, and others has been transmitted over many years, includingthe oral tradition.

445362C219054DCABF4C41560B104EA5.description: Provide specific examples of Indigenous knowledge in understanding the components of their ecosystems

C67DDEFF2EE74FB1AE8D2D6189EB0F46.description: Examine key aspects of Indigenous knowledge and First Nations and Métis people’s practices that contribute to understanding of ecosystems and the interactions oftheir components.

9F12D8E91E1048A3967DD6C7A96F277A.description: Gather information about traditional Indigenous practices with respect to the relationships and connections between people and their ecological environment.

45DFDEB09A83413C952F5062975EEDAC.description: Relate key aspects of Indigenous knowledge to their understanding of ecosystems.
